pros: I loved my time at Global Citizen Year. The team is passionate about the work they are doing and genuinely care about each other. Everyone is a continuous learner—striving to be better both personally and professionally. I felt very supported by my manager and teammates. Values like integrity, honestly, accountability and vulnerability were modeled from the top down. The organization takes its commitment to DEIA seriously by constantly examining what they are doing well and where they can improve. I deeply admired my colleagues and feel like I am a better employee and person after working at Global Citizen Year.
cons: I wouldn't say this is necessarily a con, but the organization does move quickly and is constantly pivoting to grow, try new things, and adapt to our ever-changing world. This is exciting and challenging in a good way but it does mean that you need to feel passionate about the work.

review_title: I loved working at Global Citizen Year!
job_title: Strategy & Evaluation Manager in West Oakland, CA
pros:

- You will meet some of the most incredible people you've ever met in your professional career.
- You'll have colleagues who'll inspire you.

In my experience, if you truly believe in the mission of the organization, value good work culture, opportunities for growth & diversity -- you are at the right place!

review_title: Great leadership, Great Culture, Great Opportunities for growth
pros:
I worked at Global Citizen Year for over 5 years, and truly enjoyed my time there.  The leadership of the organization is transparent, approachable, and genuinely values feedback from staff (and then implements it!). My fellow colleagues are smart, caring, fun and invested in their work and the mission. The organization stands behind its values around diversity, equity and inclusion - talking the talk and walking the walk! This was really important to me as a person of color. 

Leadership is also committed to individual growth and development. In addition to being promoted, when I outgrew the role I was initially hired for I was able to work with management to figure out how to best leverage my skills towards the needs of the organization. I was supported to develop skills I didn't yet have (but wanted to).

review_title: Great idea in theory, reprehensible business practices
pros: The theory underpinning Global Citizen Year is fantastic. Who would disagree with sending 18-year-olds to developing countries to get a dose of the real world before spending tens (or hundreds) of thousands of dollars on a college education?
cons: The image that the leadership puts forth to the public and its funders is entirely different from the way in which employees and paying students are treated. Salaries are decided on the whim of the hiring manager, with little regard for educational background or experience. Employees are worked to the bone. Secrecy and disingenuous dealings with employees is the status quo.

review_title: Great Mission Blighted by Poor Management and Lack of Leadership at Country Level
pros:
Global Citizen Year's mission is making an impact in young adult's lives and it is evident that employees are very passionate about the mission.  The US based staff are working hard to bring the vision and program improvements to the respective countries. The headquarters seems like it has a good office culture and work environment.

Team Leaders have a very flexible schedule and the independence to manage time and plan tasks and activities on their own.  As a TL you are able to work from home often and a computer (Mac Airbook laptop) and Google phone is provided to you.  You'll work on a rather small team which is beneficial in having your voice heard, working together, collaboration, bonding etc.

The benefits are generous: health care coverage + spouse/long-term partner, continuous learning stipend of $100 to use for non professional activities, professional development stipend of $500, adequate vacation time allotted for Team Leaders after the program cycle and around winter holidays.
cons:
Management and leadership at the country level is evidently lacking, and is the root cause of many frustrations, even expressed by the program's Fellows. There is an apparent disconnect between HQ and country teams, and there are many inconsistencies regarding the organization's policies, procedures, and protocol. Management seems to make off the cuff decisions and are not present or accountable to their teams or fellows. Management is not willing to listen to or appreciate the opinions of team members, and seems to feel threatened when an employee is too opinionated or offers suggestions/alternatives.  
Employees are not encouraged to take advantage of benefits (health care, stipends) so you will have to put pressure on the organization to receive them. Management is constantly looking for ways to cut program costs, and do so at the expense and to the frustration of the employees and Fellows. The passion for the mission and the organization's principles is non-existent at the country level.

A Team Leader is on call basically 24/7 for fellow's needs. TLs often work on the weekends (you're allowed the following workday off) however this, in addition to holidays are often overlooked, so you can feel like you're constantly working, and it can be difficult in the environment to claim these rights/speak up about it.

A major inconsistency across countries is the lack of organization with regards to Health and Safety. Some countries have Health and Safety Managers, others don't. TLs are provided basic first aid training, but are often expected to take on the entire role of Health and Safety Manager without proper training, including emergency response and mental health issues. This is extremely concerning as TLs are not properly trained to handle these situations, let alone have the capacity to do both roles. Long days sitting at a clinic is a regular routine as a TL, which is tedious and can make you feel unproductive and stagnant. 

There is very little room for growth in the Team Leader role and management lacks in helping to navigate the role and improve skills or provide advice when needed. You learn as you go, but it is up to you to figure things out and work on improving your skills (i.e. coaching/mentoring), with limited support. There is no career path for a TL or to move up in the company. If you're looking to "grow your career path" this is a dead end. 

TLs are extremely under-compensated, although the role is advertised to have a "competitive local salary." The keyword here is local. If you are a national, this could be a good opportunity for you, however if you're an expat/foreigner, be prepared to be shocked by the below poverty line (US) annual salary, and don't expect to be able to do more than meet your basic needs each month (especially if you have student loan debt).

review_title: Highly recommended! It was an honor to spend 4 years working with them as a team leader.
pros:
- Working at Global Citizen Year was an absolutely fantastic experience, from which I learnt a lot and that provided me with a broad set of transferable skills as well as incredible life experience. 
- There are many different aspects of the job, which definitely keeps things interesting : working with local partners, organizing and leading trainings, 1:1 coaching and mentorship, emergency response and risk management. 
- The philosophy and approach to holistic and experiential education that Global Citizen Year has developed is one with which I strongly resonate. It was truly an honor to a part of, and have an effect on, a profoundly impactful experience for so many incredible young people from many different backgrounds. 
-  For me, the work was relatively flexible, having a large degree of control over my schedule and responsibilities, though also often working with a small team to organize events, and set up and run all aspects of the program. 
- The broader Global Citizen Year program, with teams spread across 5 countries, is also a pleasure to be a part of, to learn from and contribute to. It was so rewarding to have colleagues from so many different countries, based in vastly different locations around the world, yet to have a common set of values, experiences and values that bound us together.
- There is a genuine sense that the organization as a whole is truly committed to the vision and mission that it espouses and the leadership at Global Citizen Year is incredible. Each year that I worked there felt very different from the last as there always seemed to be a willingness to improve and refine the program.
cons:
- Being a team leader is not something that I could do forever. It can be very intense and at times frustrating (although equally there are slower periods in which to recover). 
- Given the nature of the work and the relatively small country teams, there is limited room for progression. However, the team leader role provides skills and experience that are highly valuable for other employers.

pros:
The company culture thrives around the the experience of the Fellows themselves, and tends to attract an amazing clientele of young leaders and curious global citizens ready to explore the world.  
 It has a young and experimental vibe- there is lots of enthusiasm as the firm expands and refines its product. The organization is extremely vocal about why we do what we do, exploring and refining quality at every step of the way- it is a great way to get familiar with Design Thinking and building the bridge year movement from the ground up. 

It provides great training and travel opportunities internationally and locally, and exposure to students and situations of all kinds.  It will provide great insight into experiential education and intercultural adaptation, emergency response and the international workplace.
cons:
Practically speaking there is little security in terms of your position expectations or day to day tasks. The firm is attempting rapid expansion and the workplace is highly chaotic and unreliable in terms of what it can promise employees for the year, let alone a longer career.  

Although they try to focus on highest quality student experience, they have yet to refine a lot of the baseline logistical and internal processes at the firm.  Your job may regularly ask you to move, change roles or tasks with minimal training and in a fast paced work environment.  This refers to location, compensation, colleagues and work-life balance. 

The Communication and feedback model between the US based headquarters and various field staff is yet to be fluid and effective.  

The turnover can be fast-paced meaning that it is rare to meet someone truly experienced who has been around long enough to support a stable company culture and work environment.  

At times there is a lot of talk about ethics and values- which is great; but at times lacking is practicality, and this can be extremely frustrating and exhausting when already working in a chaotic working environment.

review_title: Exceptional team on a mission to change the world

review_title: Loving my work at Global Citizen Year
pros:
-Inspiring mission: we offer a life-changing experience for young leaders from diverse backgrounds
-Results-driven organization that uses both data and technology in innovative ways
-Fabulous people who are curious about the world and passionate about what they do

cons: Small team - everyone wears lots of hats! But this can also be stimulating.

pros:
GCY can provide a transformative experience for Fellows, there are real opportunities for them to grow during the program. 
Also, the curriculum design is great for expanding upon the lived experiences in the Fellows' host communities. 
And lastly, there are many great and interesting people that work for the organization in the different host countries and in the Oakland office.
cons:
This organization does not fairly compensate those working in the Team Leader role. Team Leaders are expected to constantly care for Fellows and at times are made to handle emergency and mental health situations that are outside of the scope of their capabilities. 
The organization also does not value the host countries or think much of the needs of host families and apprenticeship hosts. GCY does not "practice what they preach" when it comes to compensating and valuing local communities. Instead they look for ways to cut cost and save money, at the expense of host communities. 
The organization is run by very smart people, who know what they are doing with their branding and marketing decisions. But potential employees beware, you should know before applying that GCY is a business, and at the end of the day the most important thing for management is profit. Management is great at making you feel like you voice matters and that you are engaged in important work. But when they are tested, they will show that they value profit and power over principles.
